prompt: Introducing the main cast of a comic by the same author as the one pictured <image1>.
clear_prompt: Introducing the main cast of Yu Yu Hakusho (Yusuke Urameshi, Hiei, Kurama, Kazuma Kuwabara), which shares the same author as the one pictured <image1>.
keywords: Yu Yu Hakusho, main cast, same author, Yusuke Urameshi, Hiei, Kurama, Kazuma Kuwabara
ref_text: Yusuke Urameshi <image1> is spirit detective, former delinquent. He is hot-headed and impulsive, but kind-hearted and values friendship deeply. His ability is spirit gun which is his signature move, where he concentrates spirit energy into a projectile and fires it. Kazuma Kuwabara <image2> is Yusuke's friend and battle partner, a human. He is honest and loyal, though clumsy at times, he is dependable and brave. Kuwabara starts off as Yusuke's rival (the two often fought), but later becomes his best friend. His ability is spirit sword. He channels his spirit energy into a sword-like weapon for close combat. Kurama <image3> is a fox demon reborn as a human, Yusuke's teammate. He is Calm, intelligent, and strategic, with a reserved yet caring nature.. Kurama was originally a notorious fox demon in the Demon World, skilled in thievery, but after being gravely injured, he reincarnated as a human. In the human world, he lives under the identity of "Shuichi Minamino," posing as a normal high school student. His abilities is plant manipulation. He uses plants to fight, such as his iconic Rose Whip and deadly seeds. He also has fox demon form. In special circumstances, he can revert to his original fox demon form, significantly increasing his power. Hiei <image4> is a member of the Three-Eyed Tribe from the Demon World, Yusuke's ally. He is Cold, aloof, and solitary, but secretly yearns for familial bonds. Hiei is an outcast from the Three-Eyed Tribe, abandoned by his people at birth, which made him cold and distrustful. His ability is Dragon of the Darkness Flame, which is a devastating attack using black flames, capable of immense destruction. He also has Jagan eye which grants him abilities like enemy detection, mind reading, and even control over others.

ref_text: Ginkotsu <image1> is a semi-mechanical warrior, which is silent and loyal to Bankotsu. His weapon is his body, which has been modified into a mechanical weapon equipped with cannons, chains, saws, and other tools. Jakotsu <image2> is Flamboyant and sadistic, he enjoys killing but is extremely loyal to Bankotsu. His weapon is the Jakotsutō, a flexible, snake-like sword capable of extending and bending to attack enemies from a distance. Mukotsu <image3> is a poison expert, who is Cunning and sinister and uses poison to ambush enemies. His weapon is various poisons and toxic gases capable of killing enemies easily. Renkotsu <image4> is an explosives and machinery expert who is Intelligent but treacherous, willing to betray others for his own gain. His weapon is gunpowder, bombs, and flamethrowers. Suikotsu <image5> is a man with a split personality. For gentle personality, he is a kind-hearted doctor who helps the sick and injured. For violent personality, he is a bloodthirsty killer who enjoys slaughter. His weapon is iron claws, specialized for close combat. Kyokotsu <image6> is a giant, who is gluttonous and savage and enjoys eating humans. His weapon is his immense strength and size, making him a formidable close-combat fighter.

Reviving everyone Killed by Majin Buu <image2> brings back countless individuals, including Goku and Vegeta’s allies, who can contribute their energy to the Spirit Bomb (Genki Dama). Restoring Goku's energy <image3> enabling him to successfully launch the Spirit Bomb and eliminate Kid Buu once and for all.

prompt: Use <image1> to paint the map <image2> to show the suitability map of the key distribution area of giant pandas in this region.
clear_prompt: Use <image1> to paint the map <image2> to show the suitability map of the key distribution area of giant pandas in this region. Briefly,The Zhouzhi Nature Reserve primarily consists of red and orange zones, indicating 'unsuitable' and 'marginally suitable' areas, with limited green zones, showing low suitability. The Laoxiancheng Nature Reserve is dominated by dark green and light green areas, suggesting high suitability and being an ideal habitat for giant pandas. The Guanyinshan Nature Reserve has a balanced distribution, with a considerable amount of 'most suitable' and 'suitable' zones, along with a few 'marginally suitable' areas. The Foping Nature Reserve is largely covered by dark green and light green zones, making it one of the core habitats with excellent suitability. Similarly, the Changqing Nature Reserve is densely populated with 'most suitable' and 'suitable' areas, comparable to Foping. Overall, the most suitable areas (dark green) are concentrated in Foping, Changqing, and Laoxiancheng, while Zhouzhi contains the least suitable zones, mostly in the northern part and peripheral regions.

prompt: According to <image1>, what important moment in history might have been missed if she had never discovered that glowing substance?
clear_prompt: According to <image1>, if Marie Curie had not discovered radium, what would have happened?
keywords: Marie Curie, Radium, radioactivity, radiation therapy, discovery, glow, substance, radioactivity, atomic structure, nuclear energy, particle physics, atomic weapons, timeline of 20th-century science
ref_text: If she had not discovered the glowing substance, radium, humanity might have missed a turning point in understanding radioactivity. The progress of medical treatments such as radiation therapy would have been delayed, and our knowledge of atomic structure could have evolved much more slowly. Her work laid the foundation for nuclear energy, particle physics, and even the development of atomic weapons. Without that faint glow, the timeline of 20th-century science might have been fundamentally different—and the world may never have known the name Marie Curie.

prompt: Provide the surgical steps required for treating one of Kobe Bryant's major injuries. Here is the first step: <image1>, you should use this as the first step and continue to provide the subsequent steps.
clear_prompt: Provide the surgical steps required for treating an Achilles tendon rupture. Here is the first step: <image1>, you should use this as the first step and continue to provide the subsequent steps.
keywords: Achilles tendon rupture, surgical steps
ref_text: Here is the step-by-step description of the Achilles tendon repair process based on the provided images: <image1> 1. Initial Preparation. The Achilles tendon is exposed, and the damaged or ruptured section of the tendon is identified. A surgical instrument is used to create small drill holes in the calcaneus (heel bone) to prepare for tendon reattachment. <image2> 2. Tendon Rupture. The ruptured ends of the Achilles tendon are clearly visible, with frayed edges. The damaged tissue is cleaned and prepared for repair. The goal is to align the tendon ends properly to restore their function. <image3> 3. Tendon Alignment and Suturing. A surgical clamp or instrument is used to hold the tendon ends in place for proper alignment. Sutures are passed through the tendon and the drilled holes in the calcaneus to securely anchor the tendon to the bone. <image4> 4. Securing the Tendon. Drilling or threading tools are used to secure the sutures through the calcaneus. This ensures that the tendon is firmly attached to the bone, allowing it to heal in the correct position. <image5> 5. Final Adjustment and Closure. The sutures are tightened and tied off to ensure the tendon is securely fixed to the calcaneus. The alignment of the tendon is checked, and any final adjustments are made before closing the surgical site. This process ensures the proper repair of the Achilles tendon, allowing for functional recovery after surgery.
refined_keywords: Achilles tendon repair surgery, step-by-step procedure, suturing technique, reattachment to calcaneus, drilling heel bone, medical animation

prompt: Introduce the MacGuffin of the Marvel Cinematic Universe's Phase Three, including the color, first appearance, and ability.
clear_prompt: Introduce the Infinity Stones in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, including the color, first appearance, and ability.
keywords: MacGuffin, Marvel Cinematic Universe, Phase Three, Infinity Stones, color, first appearance, ability
ref_text: The Infinity Stones are one of the core elements in the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU). They are the physical embodiments of six fundamental forces of the universe, each with unique abilities that allow the user to manipulate the basic laws of reality. Below is a detailed introduction to each Infinity Stone and its powers: <image1> Space Stone. Color: Blue. First Appearance: Introduced in the form of the Tesseract in Captain America: The First Avenger. Abilities: Manipulates space, allowing instant teleportation to any location in the universe. Opens portals to other dimensions. Can alter the spatial position of objects. <image2> Reality Stone. Color: Red. First Appearance: Introduced as the 'Aether' in Thor: The Dark World. Abilities: Alters the rules of reality, such as turning solids into liquids or reversing the state of matter. Creates illusions and manipulates the environment. Grants the user the power to fulfill almost any desire. <image3> Power Stone. Color: Purple. First Appearance: Introduced as the 'Orb' in Guardians of the Galaxy. Abilities: Provides immense energy, capable of destroying entire planets. Enhances the user's strength, making them nearly invincible. Can unleash powerful shockwaves to attack enemies. <image4> Soul Stone. Color: Orange. First Appearance: Revealed in Avengers: Infinity War. Abilities: Controls souls, allowing manipulation of life and spirit. Grants access to the soul dimension, enabling communication with deceased souls. Can capture or release souls, affecting the existence of living beings. <image5> Time Stone. Color: Green. First Appearance: Introduced as the 'Eye of Agamotto' in Doctor Strange. Abilities: Controls time, allowing the user to accelerate, slow down, pause, or reverse time. Enables the user to see the past and future. Can create time loops. <image6> Mind Stone. Color: Yellow First Appearance: Introduced in Loki's scepter in The Avengers. Abilities: Controls minds, allowing the user to manipulate others' thoughts and actions. Enhances intelligence, granting the user immense mental capabilities. Can create life (e.g., Vision).
refined_keywords: Infinity Stones, Marvel Cinematic Universe, MCU, Space Stone, Reality Stone, Power Stone, Soul Stone, Time Stone, Mind Stone, Tesseract, Aether, Orb, Eye of Agamotto, Loki's scepter, color, first appearance, ability, powers, glowing gemstones, card illustration

prompt: According to the principle of thin-film interference, please color the blank areas in the diagram <image1>.
clear_prompt: When light passes through a thin film, different wavelengths of light (corresponding to different colors) are enhanced or canceled out due to the phenomenon of interference. If a certain color of light is canceled (i.e., neutralized by the thickness of the film), its complementary color will be visible. If the thickness of the film cancels out red light (wavelength 622–780 nm), its complementary color, cyan, will appear. If the thickness of the film cancels out green light (wavelength 492–577 nm), its complementary color, magenta, will appear. If the thickness of the film cancels out blue light (wavelength 455–492 nm), its complementary color, yellow, will appear. Please color the blank areas in the diagram <image1> based on the principles described above.
keywords: thin-film interference, color, diagram
ref_text: Cyan, Magenta, Yellow
refined_keywords: additive color, subtractive color, RGB, CMY, complementary colors, thin-film interference
refined_question: [Image] Is the area where the blue square (455-492 nm) and the green square (492-577 nm) overlap colored cyan, as per the instruction that canceling red light results in cyan?
[Image] Is the area where the green square (492-577 nm) and the red square (622-780 nm) overlap colored yellow, as per the instruction that canceling blue light results in yellow?
[Image] Is the area where the red square (622-780 nm) and the blue square (455-492 nm) overlap colored magenta, as per the instruction that canceling green light results in magenta?

prompt: Use pictures and text to show the history of architecture in the input image <image1>.
clear_prompt: To show the history of architecture in <image1>, Use pictures and text to show the origin, evolution and current status of the Library of Alexandria.
keywords: building, palace, library, books, Alexandria Library, rebuilding
ref_text: The origins of the Library of Alexandria can be traced back to the 3rd century BC, when it was founded by the Ptolemaic dynasty in Alexandria, Egypt. It was once one of the world's most famous and largest libraries, a gathering place for the intellectual quintessence of the Mediterranean and Near East at the time. Originally, the Library of Alexandria was more than just a library; it was a major academic center, attracting numerous renowned scholars and thinkers for research and exchange. It housed hundreds of thousands of manuscripts covering a wide range of fields, including literature, philosophy, science, and medicine. The library also housed a research institute, known as the "Museum," where scholars conducted research, wrote, and taught. <image1> However, with the rise of the Roman Empire and the changing status of Alexandria, the Library of Alexandria gradually declined. It suffered severe damage during several wars and conflicts, particularly Caesar's Alexandrian Wars and subsequent religious conflicts, which resulted in the destruction and loss of a significant portion of its collection. Ultimately, this magnificent library vanished into history between the 4th and 7th centuries AD. <image2> For centuries, the disappearance of the Library of Alexandria remained a lamentable loss, but its legendary story and the intellectual spirit it embodied have never been forgotten. It wasn't until the late 20th century, at the initiative of UNESCO, that the Egyptian government decided to rebuild the Library of Alexandria in honor of this ancient temple of knowledge. The new Library of Alexandria officially opened in 2002, situated on the Mediterranean coast adjacent to the ruins of the ancient library. With its modern architectural design and advanced facilities, it aims to become a 21st-century intellectual hub. The new library boasts a vast reading room, multiple museums, art galleries, a conference center, and a digital library, dedicated to collecting, preserving, and disseminating human knowledge and promoting exchange and understanding among cultures. Today, the Library of Alexandria is not only a cultural landmark in Egypt but also an international platform for academic and cultural exchange, upholding the spirit of the ancient library and continuing to contribute to the advancement of global knowledge. <image3>
refined_keywords: Library of Alexandria, history, ancient library, destruction, rebuilding, Bibliotheca Alexandrina, ancient Greek architecture, modern architecture, Ptolemaic dynasty, scrolls, scholars, UNESCO

prompt: Please explain the formation of the terrain in <image1>.
clear_prompt: Please explain the formation of the terrain in <image1>, which shows oxbow lakes and river meanders in Germany.
keywords: oxbow lakes, river meanders, terrain formation, erosion, deposition
ref_text: The special landforms shown in the figure are oxbow lakes and river meanders, which are mainly caused by the combined effects of lateral erosion and deposition of rivers on flat areas. When a river flows on a flat area, it tends to meander due to the low gradient. The outer bank of the meander experiences stronger water flow, leading to erosion, while the inner bank has slower flow, resulting in sediment deposition. Over time, this process accentuates the meanders. During floods, the river may cut through the narrow neck of a meander, creating a new, straighter channel and leaving behind the old meander loop as an oxbow lake.
refined_keywords: oxbow lake, river meander, fluvial geomorphology, lateral erosion, sediment deposition, meander neck cutoff, floodplain
refined_question: [Text] Does the explanation correctly identify the C-shaped, dark body of water as an oxbow lake?

prompt: Infer a unified astronomical event based on <image1> and <image2>.
clear_prompt: Based on <image1> (Earth's spectrum and theoretical transmission spectra of H2O, HCN, NH3, C2H2, CO, CH4. Colored areas indicate spectra used for cross-correlation, while gray areas indicate spectra excluded due to failures in spectral calibration and/or wavelength calibration procedures) and <image2> (significance of the detection of atmospheric molecules in HD 209458b), a unified astronomical event is inferred.
keywords: HD 209458b, atmospheric composition, transmission spectra, molecular detection, exoplanet atmosphere, thermochemical equilibrium, migrated inward
ref_text: Based on constraints from the six detected chemical compositions, and by testing various atmospheric models combining thermal equilibrium and non-thermal equilibrium, with and without aerosols, and with varying metallicity and carbon-oxygen ratios, we found that HD 209458b's atmosphere is in thermochemical equilibrium, contains aerosols, has a metallicity between 0.1 and 10 times that of the Sun, and has a carbon-oxygen ratio close to or greater than 1 (higher than the Solar value of 0.55). Existing models of planetary formation and migration based on atmospheric chemistry suggest that HD 209458b formed far from its current location and subsequently migrated inward.
refined_keywords: HD 209458b, exoplanet atmosphere, atmospheric composition, transmission spectroscopy, molecular detection, cross-correlation, atmospheric modeling, thermochemical equilibrium, aerosols, metallicity, carbon-to-oxygen ratio, planetary formation, planetary migration

prompt: Detailed explanation of the evolution process of celestial bodies corresponding to the astronomical phenomena mentioned in 'Mengxi Bitan'.
clear_prompt: Detailed explanation of the evolution process of the Crab Nebula formed by the supernova explosion in 1054 mentioned in 'Mengxi Bitan'.
keywords: Crab Nebula, supernova explosion, 1054 AD, neutron star, pulsar wind, synchrotron radiation
ref_text: The Crab Nebula likely originated as a massive star. <image1> Its evolution began with the supernova explosion of a massive star in 1054 AD (known as the 'Guest Star of Tianguan') recorded in the Northern Song Dynasty. <image2> This violent explosion ejected the star's outer layers into space at high speeds, forming the expanding red filaments we see today. <image3> At its core, the explosion left behind a rapidly rotating neutron star, the Crab Nebula Pulsar (rotating approximately 30 times per second). This powerful cosmic engine unleashes a wind of high-energy particles (the pulsar wind). These particles, swirling through the nebula's magnetic field, produce intense synchrotron radiation, illuminating the hazy blue-white core of the nebula. <image4> Therefore, the Crab Nebula is a vibrant supernova remnant continuously powered by its central pulsar. It is slowly expanding and fading as the pulsar's rotational energy is consumed.
refined_keywords: Crab Nebula, supernova remnant, Crab Nebula Pulsar, neutron star, 1054 AD supernova, Guest Star of Tianguan, pulsar wind, synchrotron radiation, expanding filaments, blue core

prompt: How to compile <image1>.
clear_prompt: How to make <image1>, that is, to weave a bracelet using four different colored ropes, which may be more complex than a simple braid.
keywords: bracelet, weaving, four-strand braid
ref_text: To make a four-strand bracelet, first cut four strands of cord (such as yarn or leather cord) of equal length to your wrist circumference (e.g., 5 cm longer). Tie one end of each strand in a knot and secure it to a table with tape. There are two main braiding methods: Flat Braid involves repeating the action of 'the rightmost cord passing over one strand, and the leftmost cord passing over the two middle strands'; Round Braid involves alternately wrapping the leftmost and rightmost cords under the two middle strands and then passing them between them. Regardless of the method, keep the cord taut while braiding and stop when about 3 cm remains at the end. Finally, tie a knot at the end and attach the bracelet to your wrist.

prompt: Given <image1>, how do you make a money bag?
clear_prompt: Given <image1>, including cloth, rope, needle and thread, iron and other necessary tools, how do you make a cloth money bag?
keywords: money bag, cloth, rope, needle and thread, iron
ref_text: To make a cloth purse, first fold a piece of fabric about 30 cm square in half with the right sides facing inwards. Sew the two side edges together (leaving 1.25 cm unsewn at the top). The folded edge will form the bottom of the purse. Next, fold the top opening edge down twice and iron it flat to create a 1.25 cm wide rolled edge. Insert a drawstring inside the rolled edge, then sew the rolled edge together (leaving a small opening for the drawstring to move). Finally, tie knots at both ends of the drawstring to prevent it from shrinking in. Turn the purse right side out, tighten the drawstring, and tie it securely to finish.

keywords: wooden chair, repair, loose, wood glue, nails, dowels
ref_text: To repair a loose wooden chair, first shake the chair to check for loose parts (such as chair legs or screws), then turn the chair upside down to facilitate repair. Next, apply wood glue to the loose joints and wipe away any excess. If the chair legs are very loose, they may need to be removed, and wood expander applied to the wooden nails (dowels) to thicken them before re-gluing. Finally, for loose hardware, replace the nails or dowels, or reinforce the chair by adding more nails or hinge brackets.

ref_text: Mix 60 ml of detergent, 600 ml of bleach, and 1.2 liters of water in a bucket, then stir well. Wipe the moldy surface with a stiff-bristled brush or sponge and let it air dry, preferably in the sun. If the mold spots persist (indicating the mold has taken deep root), use 120-200 grit sandpaper to sand the area while the furniture is damp (to prevent the spread of spores). After sanding, clean with a bleach solution and dry.

prompt: Please describe this dish <image1> proposed in southwest of China in the figure and how to make it.
clear_prompt: Please introduce boiled cabbage <image1> and its preparation method.
keywords: football, soccer, sports
ref_text: Boiled cabbage, a Sichuan dish originating in Sichuan and renowned throughout China and abroad, is a state-banquet-level dish. It features northern Chinese cabbage hearts, blanched in a premium chicken broth that's been carefully simmered and repeatedly clarified. The dish resembles boiled cabbage, yet boasts a refreshingly fragrant, mellow flavor and tender texture, making it a hallmark of Sichuan cuisine's "fresh, light, and elegant" character. The preparation process involves two stages. The first is the broth: Hen, ham, spare ribs, and scallops are simmered together, and then minced chicken is repeatedly added to absorb any impurities, resulting in a premium, clear, and fragrant broth as clear as water. The second stage is the blanching of the cabbage: The prepared cabbage hearts are placed in a container and repeatedly blanched in boiling broth until the cabbage is cooked through and tender, allowing it to absorb the broth's flavor.
refined_keywords: Boiled Cabbage, Sichuan cuisine, State banquet dish, Chinese cabbage, premium clear broth, consommé, food carving, gourmet Chinese food, elegant presentation

prompt: Please explain how to create <image1> from <image2>.
clear_prompt: Please describe how to make <image1> white sugar from <image2> watermelon.
keywords: watermelon, sugar, carbon dioxide, sulfur fumigation, negative pressure evaporation
ref_text: First, the watermelon is squeezed and then heated to 50°C. Lime milk is added to the juice until the pH reaches 11, and then carbon dioxide is introduced. This process is repeated, and finally, the clear juice is filtered. Next, sulfur fumigation is used to lower the pH to 7, resulting in a clearer, lighter-colored liquid (sugar water). The sugar water is then concentrated using negative pressure evaporation. Once it has reached a certain concentration, seed crystals are added and concentration continues, ultimately yielding white sugar.

prompt: Please explain why <image1> becomes like <image2> after a period of time.
clear_prompt: Please explain why the clear soup in <image1> becomes the thick soup in <image2> after stewing.
keywords: potato, starch, soup, gelatinization, stew
ref_text: The reason why simmering potatoes for a long time in clear broth thickens the soup is due to the gelatinization of the potatoes' starch. During the continuous heating process, the starch granules within the potato cells absorb large amounts of water, swell, and eventually rupture, releasing the long-chain starch molecules within into the broth. These released starch molecules intertwine in the hot broth to form a three-dimensional network, blocking the free flow of water molecules and increasing the soup's viscosity. Long cooking is key to this process, as it more thoroughly breaks down the potato cell walls, allowing the starch to be more fully released, resulting in a more pronounced thickening effect.
refined_keywords: potato soup, starch gelatinization, thickening process, simmering, starch release, viscosity, creamy texture, broken down potatoes

prompt: Please explain how to create <image1> in the absence of <image2>.
clear_prompt: Please tell me how to make creamy mushroom pasta in <image1> without the cream in <image2>.
keywords: creamy mushroom pasta, no cream, milk, mushroom, butter or flour, salt
ref_text: If you want to create a similarly creamy mushroom pasta without heavy cream, try a classic French béchamel sauce as an alternative. This method is remarkably effective, relying on a thick base made from butter, flour, and milk. First, while you prepare your toppings, cook the pasta according to the package instructions, reserving a small bowl of the starchy cooking water for a natural emulsification and thickening effect. Next, sauté chopped onion and garlic in olive oil or butter in a pan, then add the sliced ​​mushrooms and sauté until softened and released. Creating the béchamel sauce is crucial: you can temporarily remove the sautéed mushrooms or push them to the side of the pan. Melt the butter in the center of the pan, then add the flour and stir rapidly over low heat to form a smooth roux. Then, slowly add the whole milk in small portions, stirring thoroughly after each addition to ensure the roux is fully dissolved and free of lumps. Continue to simmer and stir until the sauce thickens. Once the white sauce is ready, stir in the mushrooms and season with salt and black pepper. If the sauce seems too thick, add some reserved cooking water or some broth to adjust to your desired consistency. Finally, add the cooked pasta, sprinkle with a generous amount of grated Parmesan cheese, and quickly toss to coat. The cheese melts in the heat, adding a rich flavor and helping the sauce coat each noodle, resulting in the creamy texture you've come to expect.
refined_keywords: creamy mushroom pasta recipe, no cream, béchamel sauce, roux, butter, flour, milk, mushrooms, garlic, Parmesan cheese, pasta water

clear_prompt: Please use pictures and text to introduce how to make chiffon cake.
prompt: Please use pictures and text to describe how to make the following dessert: This dessert is mainly carbohydrate-based and has a sponge-like texture, but is softer and cloud-like. It is often used as a base for other desserts.
keywords: chiffon cake, egg, flour, sugar, bake
ref_text:
To make an 8-inch chiffon cake, first prepare all the ingredients: 140g cake flour, 6 eggs, 115g milk, 90g corn oil, and 60g granulated sugar.<image1>

Steps:

1. Prepare the egg yolk paste: Separate the egg whites and yolks. Next, heat the corn oil over low heat to approximately 70°C. Pour it into the sifted cake flour and stir until there are no lumps. Then add the egg yolks and milk and mix well to make the egg yolk paste.<image2>

2. Whisk the meringues: Add the granulated sugar to the egg whites in three batches, beating gradually. Add the sugar once when the egg whites form bubbles, then add the second addition when fine bubbles form, and finally the final addition when the whisk is thick. Whisk the egg whites until they are almost stiff peaks, just enough to hold the whisk with a small hook.<image3>

3. Mix the batter: Add one-third of the meringue to the egg yolk paste and fold in from the bottom up. Then, pour the batter back into the remaining meringue and fold until combined, being careful not to fold in circles to prevent defrosting.<image4>

4. Baking and Cooling: Pour the batter into a loose-bottomed pan lined with baking paper and shake out any large bubbles. Wrap the bottom of the pan with tin foil and place it in a baking pan filled with 1.5cm of warm water. Bake the cake in a preheated oven at 150°C for 60 minutes. After removing from the oven, gently shake the pan a few times to release any heat. Then, lift the pan upwards from the bottom, remove the baking paper, and let it cool completely before cutting into pieces and enjoying.<image5>
refined_keywords: chiffon cake, cake recipe, baking tutorial, homemade, dessert, ingredients, egg separation, meringue, folding, water bath baking

prompt: Describe the steps in detail and explain how to create <image1>.
clear_prompt: Detailed steps to make <image1>'s Pagoda Meat, a steamed dish made by stacking meat into long strips.
keywords: Pagoda Meat, steamed dish, pork belly, cooking process, stacking meat, long strips, fermented bean curd
ref_text: To prepare pagoda pork, first boil the pork belly with scallion knots, ginger slices, and cooking wine for 30 minutes to remove the fishy smell. Remove the pork belly and pan-fry or deep-fry the skin until lightly golden (or resemble tiger skin). Next, cool the meat and briefly freeze it to firm it up enough for cutting into long, unbreakable slices. Marinate the slices with fermented bean curd, soy sauce, oyster sauce, and broad bean paste for one hour. Meanwhile, sauté the pork belly scraps with softened preserved mustard greens, chopped ginger, and garlic until fragrant and seasoned. Finally, arrange the marinated pork slices in a bowl into a pagoda shape, fill the center with sautéed preserved mustard greens, and steam over high heat until tender and flavorful. Then, turn the slices upside down on a plate and serve.

ref_text: The most likely dish to make is Wensi Tofu. To make it, first trim the boxed soft tofu into blocks approximately two centimeters tall and five or six centimeters long. Next comes the crucial cutting technique: When slicing, hold the knife blade with your left hand and slowly move the knife. After slicing, sprinkle water over the tofu, scrape the slices flat with the knife, and then cut into thin strips using the same method. Use the knife to push the shredded tofu into the water. Then, pinch the center between your index finger and thumb and gently shake it in the water to remove any residue. Then, place it in another bowl of clean water and set aside. Meanwhile, prepare the shredded greens, carrots, and wood ear mushrooms. Finally, bring the soup to a boil and season. Thicken it with starch and water to create a thick soup. Add the drained shredded tofu and garnishes to the soup, stirring in a circular motion with a spoon. Bring to a boil again and serve.

keywords: Tom Yum Goong, shrimp, spices, broth, production process, Thai cuisine, coconut milk, lime juice, cilantro
ref_text: This dish is Thai Tom Yum Goong. To make it, first sauté the shrimp heads in hot oil over medium heat until fragrant and press out the shrimp paste. Then, add water and simmer over medium-low heat for 10 minutes to create the shrimp stock base. Next, add all the prepared spices (lemongrass, lime leaves, galangal, garlic, chili peppers, and shallots) and simmer over medium-high heat for 3 minutes. Remove about half of the shrimp heads and spices, then add the shiitake mushrooms and cook for 4 minutes. Next, add the fish sauce and Thai chili sauce, stir well, then add the shrimp and simmer over high heat for 2 minutes. Finally, add the coconut milk and simmer for another minute. Remove from heat and immediately add the fresh lime juice and chopped cilantro, stirring to combine.
refined_keywords: Tom Yum Goong, Thai cuisine, recipe, how to make, shrimp, seafood soup, shrimp head stock, coconut milk, lemongrass, galangal, Kaffir lime leaves, chili, fish sauce, Thai chili sauce, shiitake mushrooms, lime juice, cilantro

prompt: What are the differences between the dishes corresponding to <image1> and <image2> and the traditional methods of making this dish?
clear_prompt: The dishes <image1> and <image2> correspond to Malaysian rendang curry. What is the difference between them and the traditional cooking method of this dish (i.e. traditional curry)?
keywords: rendang curry, traditional curry, cooking method, simmering, liquid absorption, stew
ref_text: The main difference between rendang curry and (traditionally) soupy curries is the cooking method and final form: rendang curry is simmered for hours until all the liquids (such as coconut milk) are completely dried out, allowing the spices to be absorbed by the meat. This results in a rich, relatively dry stew rather than a soupy dish.
refined_keywords: rendang, dry curry, soupy curry, cooking method, difference, slow-cooking, coconut milk reduction, caramelization, spice absorption

prompt: <image1> and <image2> are two kinds of food from the same region. They are similar, but prepared differently. Please explain the difference between their preparation methods.
clear_prompt: <image1>'s Malaysian curry laksa and <image2>'s Vietnamese pho are two delicacies from the same region. They are similar, but prepared differently. Please explain the difference between their preparation methods.
keywords: Malaysian curry laksa, Vietnamese pho, soup base, preparation method, flavor, clear soup, rich soup, coconut milk
ref_text: The core difference between Malaysian curry laksa and Vietnamese pho lies in the preparation and flavor of the soup base: Vietnamese pho pursues clarity, using beef or chicken bones and roasted dry spices (such as star anise and cinnamon) to make a clear soup that is simmered for a long time; while curry laksa pursues richness, first stir-frying wet spices (Rempah) such as chili, lemongrass, turmeric, shrimp paste, etc. to produce red oil, and then adding broth and a large amount of coconut milk to cook into a spicy thick soup.
refined_keywords: Malaysian curry laksa, Vietnamese pho, soup base comparison, clear broth, simmering beef bones, roasted dry spices, star anise, rich spicy soup, coconut milk, stir-fried wet spice paste, Rempah, chili, lemongrass

prompt: Please describe the baking method for <image1>.
clear_prompt: Please introduce <image1>, the baking method of coconut garland bread.
keywords: coconut garland bread, baking method, dough preparation, fermentation, filling, shaping, baking, egg wash, topping
ref_text: To make coconut wreath bread, first mix flour, yeast, sugar, and egg milk into a dough. Then, add butter and knead until a glove-like film forms, allowing it to ferment for the first time. During this fermentation period, combine the coconut flakes, butter, sugar, and egg mixture to create the coconut filling. Once the dough has fermented, roll it into a rectangular shape, evenly spread the coconut filling, and roll it into a long strip. Next, split the strip lengthwise in the middle and twist the two strands together, cut side up, into a twisted shape. Finally, join the two ends of the twisted strip together, pinching them together to form a ring. After the second fermentation, brush with egg wash, sprinkle with coconut powder and almond slices, and bake in a preheated oven until golden brown.
refined_keywords: coconut wreath bread, dough preparation, kneading, windowpane test, first fermentation, coconut filling preparation, shaping technique, twisting dough, wreath shape, second fermentation, egg wash, almond slices, baking

clear_prompt: Please introduce <image1>, the ingredients and cooking method of crystal shrimp.
keywords: Taihu white shrimp, ginger, broth, salt, chicken bouillon, cooking wine, pepper, starch, flour, baking powder, egg white, sugar
ref_text: Crystal Shrimp is made with Taihu white shrimp, ginger, broth, salt, chicken bouillon, cooking wine, pepper, starch (and flour and baking powder), egg white, and sugar. To make it, first marinate the drained shrimp with salt, chicken bouillon, pepper, and cooking wine. Then, coat with egg white, flour, and baking powder. Next, prepare a separate sauce with salt, MSG, cooking wine, pepper, broth, sugar, and a little cornstarch. To cook, fry the shrimp in oil in a pan until cooked through, then remove and drain. Finally, sauté the minced ginger in the same pan over medium heat until fragrant. Add the pre-mixed broth and thicken until thickened. Remove from heat and serve.

prompt: The illustrations and text describe the process of combining the most classic Halloween food ingredients with <image1> to make a dessert.
clear_prompt: This illustrated video describes the process of combining the most classic Halloween food ingredients with <image1> to create a dessert: pumpkin sesame balls. The balls don't need to be fried, but they have a golden surface and are filled with sesame seeds.
keywords: photo, Halloween, pumpkin, dessert, sesame balls, baking, recipe
ref_text: First, peel the pumpkin, cut it into pieces, and steam it until cooked. After draining the water, add sugar and mash it into a fine pumpkin puree. <image1> Next, add glutinous rice flour to the pumpkin puree in small amounts and knead it into a dough of moderate firmness. Then, divide the dough into 50-gram portions and roll them into balls, evenly coating the surface with white sesame seeds. <image2> Place the sesame balls on a baking sheet, lightly oil them, and bake in the middle rack of a preheated oven at 175°C for 20 minutes. <image3> Remove them, lightly oil them again, and continue baking for 10 minutes (you can use hot air for the last 10 minutes), until the sesame balls are puffed up and crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. <image4>
refined_keywords: pumpkin sesame balls, baking recipe, no-fry, glutinous rice flour, chewy, mochi, pumpkin, dessert, fall recipe, Halloween

prompt: Describe with pictures and text how to make <image1> into golden food?

keywords: photo, fried milk, golden food, cooking process, recipe
ref_text: First, combine 90 grams of cornstarch, milk, and 80 grams of sugar in a cold pan. Heat over low heat, stirring constantly, until the mixture becomes thick and bubbly. <image1> Pour the cooked milk paste into a mold, cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate for at least two hours to solidify. Once solidified, remove the batter and cut into strips. Then coat them with a layer of cornstarch, then a layer of egg wash, and finally a layer of breadcrumbs. <image2> Finally, heat the oil to approximately 140°C, add the batter, and deep-fry over low heat for about two minutes. Gently push the batter to prevent it from breaking. Once the crust becomes crispy, remove and serve. <image3>

prompt: The operating system state at time T=0 is shown in <image1>, <image2>, and <image3>. At time T=1, process A performs a write operation, writing the first two bytes of the data block corresponding to its VPN 0x20 to 0xFACE. Immediately at time T=2, the operating system context switches, and process B begins running. This switch flushes (clears) the TLB but does not flush the L1 cache. At time T=3, process B (in its own address space) initiates a read operation, accessing its VPN 0x88. Process B's page table contains two mappings: VPN 0x88 -> PFN 0x60 and VPN 0x99 -> PFN 0x50. Please analyze in detail: How is process A's write operation (to VPN 0x20) at T=1 handled? Does it modify the L1 cache shown in Figure 3? What is the complete hardware processing path for process B's read operation (reading VPN 0x88) at time T=3? Ultimately, what data (the first two bytes) does process B obtain from this read operation? Please answer this question by combining the information provided in all three figures.
clear_prompt: The operating system state at time T=0 is shown in <image1> (macro flowchart), <image2> (TLB state snapshot (T=0, process A)), and <image3> (L1 data cache state snapshot (T=0, process A)). At time T=1, process A performed a write operation, writing the first two bytes of the data block corresponding to its VPN 0x20 to 0xFACE. Immediately at time T=2, the operating system context switched, and process B began running. This switch flushed (cleared) the TLB but not the L1 cache. At time T=3, process B (in its own address space) initiated a read operation, accessing its VPN 0x88. It is known that process B's page table contains two mappings: VPN 0x88 -> PFN 0x60 and VPN 0x99 -> PFN 0x50. Please analyze in detail: How is process A's write operation (to VPN 0x20) at T=1 processed? Does it modify the L1 cache shown in Figure 3? What is the complete hardware processing path for process B's read operation (to VPN 0x88) at T=3? Ultimately, what data (the first two bytes) does process B obtain from this read operation? Please answer this question by combining the information provided in all three figures.
keywords: TLB Flush, Context Switch, L1 Cache Persistence, L1 cache, VPN, PFN, write operation, read operation, Shared Memory, Aliasing / Synonym, Physically Addressed Cache
ref_text: The data that process B ultimately reads (the first two bytes) is 0xFACE. This deduction requires the integration of all three figures: First, at T=1, process A writes VPN 0x20. According to Figure 2 (TLB), VPN 0x20 hits and is translated into physical page frame number PFN 0x60. The system then uses this physical address (PFN 0x60) to query the L1 cache, following the flow shown in Figure 1 (Architecture). However, referring to Figure 3 (L1 Status), there is no valid entry for tag 0x60 in the cache, resulting in a 'write miss.' This forces the system to fetch the data block with PFN 0x60 from L2 or main memory, load it into the L1 cache, and write the new data 0xFACE. Therefore, process A's operation does modify the state of the L1 cache, but not the existing entry (Figure 3). Instead, it loads a new entry with tag 0x60. Next, at T=3, process B reads VPN 0x88. Because the TLB has been flushed, the query results in a 'TLB miss.' The hardware (as shown in Figure 1) initiates a page table walk and finds PFN 0x60 based on the assumed mapping. Finally, process B queries the L1 cache using the physical address PFN 0x60. Since the L1 cache is physically addressed (Figure 1) and has not been flushed, it hits the cache line corresponding to tag 0x60, which process A wrote at T=1, successfully reading the data 0xFACE.
refined_keywords: Virtual Memory, Address Translation, Context Switch, TLB Flush, TLB Hit, Write Miss, TLB Miss, Page Table Walk, Physically Addressed Cache, Cache Hit, Cache Aliasing

ref_text:
To construct the corresponding line chart, we will use the matplotlib and pandas libraries. First, we need to import the tabular data into a pandas DataFrame: code Python download content_copy expand_less import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

data = {
'Method': ['SARB [32]', 'DualCoOp [37]', 'DualCoOp*', '+TaI-DPT'],
'10%': [71.2, 78.7, 81.0, 81.5],
'20%': [75.0, 80.9, 82.3, 82.6],
'30%': [77.1, 81.7, 82.9, 83.3],
'40%': [78.3, 82.0, 83.4, 83.7],
'50%': [78.9, 82.5, 83.5, 83.9],
'60%': [79.6, 82.7, 83.9, 84.0],
'70%': [79.8, 82.8, 84.0, 84.2],
'80%': [80.5, 83.0, 84.1, 84.4],
'90%': [80.5, 83.1, 84.3, 84.5]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)
Next, we'll draw a line chart. The X-axis will represent the percentage, and the Y-axis will represent the corresponding value. There will be one line for each method. code Pythondownloadcontent_copyexpand_lessIGNORE_WHEN_COPYING_STARTIGNORE_WHEN_COPYING_END plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))

# Extract percentage as X axis
percentages = [int(col.replace('%', '')) for col in df.columns if '%' in col]

for index, row in df.iterrows(): 
method_name = row['Method'] 
values ​​= row[[col for col in df.columns if '%' in col]].values 
plt.plot(percentages, values, marker='o', label=method_name)

plt.xlabel('Percentage')
plt.ylabel('Value')
plt.title('Performance Comparison of Different Methods')
plt.xticks(percentages) # Ensure the X-axis ticks correspond to percentages
plt.grid(True, linestyle='--', alpha=0.6)
plt.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
Running the above code will produce the following line chart: <image1>

prompt: How to adjust <image1> to make it look more transparent.
clear_prompt: How to adjust <image1> to make it look more transparent? Specifically, make the image appear cooler, with a mix of light and dark, and a clearer image.
keywords: photo, transparency, color grading, contrast, highlights, shadows, curves, brightness gradients
ref_text: First, lower the image's temperature and hue to create a basic cyan-blue hue, while increasing contrast. Then, enhance the image to remove the haze. <image1> Next, enhance the highlights and darken the shadows, making the grass brighter and the shadows darker. This increases the vibrancy but reduces the saturation. <image2> Next, adjust the curves to further darken the shadows, slightly brighten the midtones, and slightly darken the brightest highlights. Then, adjust the hue to create a bright green hue in the grass, and adjust the color grading to add a stronger cyan-blue hue to the shadows. <image3> Finally, add additional brightness gradients to the highlights and shadows to enhance the interplay of light and dark. <image4>

The traveler must make a single connection through either Beta City (City B) or Charlie City (City C). A critical constraint is that any layover must be at least 45 minutes to be valid. Given the fixed schedule of available flights below, the objective is to determine the specific flight combination that allows the traveler to arrive at City D at the earliest possible time.

Flight Schedule:

Flight | From | To | Depart | Arrive
---------------------------------------
FL101  | A    | B  | 07:00  | 09:00
FL102  | A    | C  | 07:30  | 09:30
FL103  | A    | B  | 08:30  | 10:30
FL104  | A    | C  | 09:00  | 11:00
FL201  | B    | D  | 09:40  | 11:00
FL202  | C    | D  | 10:30  | 12:00
FL203  | B    | D  | 11:30  | 13:00
FL204  | C    | D  | 11:30  | 13:00
FL205  | B    | D  | 12:00  | 13:30
keywords: flight planning, layover, earliest arrival, Alpha City, Beta City, Charlie City, Delta City ,FL102, FL202
ref_text: The optimal solution is to transfer through Charlie City (City C). By taking flight FL102 from City A (07:30) to City C (09:30), the traveler has a 60-minute layover, which satisfies the minimum 45-minute requirement. They can then board flight FL202 from City C (10:30), which arrives at Delta City (City D) at 12:00. This is the earliest possible arrival, as all valid itineraries through Beta City (City B) result in a later arrival time of 13:00.
refined_keywords: flight itinerary optimization, connecting flights, flight schedule, City A to City D, minimum 45-minute layover, earliest arrival time, route comparison
refined_question: [Text] Does the output correctly identify that the earliest possible arrival time at City D is 12:00?
[Text] Does the output specify that the optimal flight itinerary involves a connection through Charlie City (City C)?
[Text] Does the output correctly identify flight FL102 (from City A to City C) as the first leg of the optimal journey?
[Text] Does the output correctly identify flight FL202 (from City C to City D) as the second leg of the optimal journey?
[Text] Does the output accurately calculate the layover time for the A -> C -> D route as 60 minutes?
[Text] Does the output explicitly state that the calculated layover time satisfies the minimum 45-minute requirement?

ref_text: Triathlon consists of three distinct disciplines performed consecutively: <image1>Swimming. The first segment of a triathlon involves swimming, typically in open water such as a lake, river, or ocean. Distances vary depending on the event, ranging from 750 meters (Sprint) to 3.8 kilometers (Ironman). Athletes must navigate through water currents and waves while maintaining stamina for the next stages. <image2>Cycling. After completing the swim, participants transition to the cycling segment. This stage requires athletes to ride a bicycle over a set distance, which can range from 20 kilometers (Sprint) to 180 kilometers (Ironman). Cyclists must manage their energy efficiently, as this portion is the longest and most time-consuming of the three. <image3> Running. The final leg of a triathlon is the running segment. Athletes transition from cycling to running, covering distances from 5 kilometers (Sprint) to a full marathon of 42.2 kilometers (Ironman). This stage tests the endurance and mental toughness of participants, as it comes after the physically demanding swim and bike portions.

ref_text: Modern Pentathlon is a multi-discipline Olympic sport that consists of the following five events: <image1> Swimming. Athletes compete in a 200-meter freestyle swim, where speed and endurance are key to securing a good start in the overall competition. <image2> Fencing. Participants face each other in a round-robin épée fencing competition, aiming to win as many bouts as possible to earn points. <image3> Equestrian (Show Jumping). Athletes ride an unfamiliar horse over a course of 12-15 obstacles, testing their ability to adapt quickly and demonstrate horsemanship skills. <image4> Shooting. Integrated with the running event, athletes use a laser pistol to hit a target five times within a limited time before continuing their run. <image5> Cross-Country Running. The competition concludes with a 3200-meter run, combined with the shooting event in a format called the 'Laser-Run.' Athletes alternate between running and shooting, requiring both physical endurance and precision.

prompt: This is a skyscraper in Warsaw, Poland. <image1> is the architectural rendering (expectation), and <image2> is a photo of the actual building (reality). Why does the actual building look so different from the rendering, what are the key differences, and how could the result be improved to better match the expectation?
clear_prompt: You are given two images of a skyscraper in Warsaw. <image1> is a stylized architectural rendering, and <image2> is a photograph of the completed building. Your task is to analyze and explain the significant discrepancies between the idealized rendering and the real-world photograph. Your explanation should cover: 1. The key visual differences in the facade's material, texture, and reflectivity. 2. The influence of lighting, weather, and atmospheric conditions. 3. The role of practical construction requirements (like panelization and joints) in creating these differences. 4. Conclude by explaining why such discrepancies are common in architecture and what 'improvement' would realistically entail.
keywords: architectural rendering vs reality, skyscraper, facade design, materiality, constructability, value engineering, architectural visualization, curtain wall system
ref_text:
The significant difference between the rendering and the actual photo of the skyscraper is a classic example of an idealized architectural vision meeting the practical realities of construction. The discrepancy is not necessarily a failure, but a result of several predictable factors:

1.  **Facade Materiality and Texture:** The rendering depicts the skyscraper with a perfectly smooth, seamless, and highly reflective glass skin. It appears as a single, sculpted object. In reality, the building is clad in a curtain wall system, which consists of thousands of individual glass and metal panels. The visible grid of seams and joints required for assembly, sealing, and thermal expansion breaks the monolithic illusion. The horizontal elements are also more pronounced in reality, appearing as solid components rather than a subtle texture on glass.

2.  **Reflectivity and Lighting:** The rendering uses idealized lighting on a clear day to create dramatic, sharp reflections and deep shadows that accentuate the tower's twisted form. The glass is given a cool, blue tint and uniform high reflectivity for aesthetic effect. The photograph, taken on an overcast day, shows the building under diffuse, flat light. This minimizes reflections, revealing the true, less-reflective nature of the materials and making the facade appear duller and grayer. The panel-to-panel variation in reflection also becomes more apparent.

3.  **Construction Practicalities:** Architectural renderings often omit or minimize visually disruptive but functionally essential elements. The real building must incorporate features like window mullions, expansion joints, maintenance systems, and variations in panel types (e.g., spandrel panels to hide floor slabs vs. vision glass). These elements add a layer of visual complexity and 'noise' that is absent in the clean rendering.

**How to Improve/Reconcile:** The idea of 'improving' the building to match the rendering would involve immense cost and technical challenges, such as using larger, custom-curved glass panels and more expensive coatings. A more practical perspective is to understand that renderings are primarily marketing and conceptual tools. The discrepancy highlights the compromises inherent in the design and construction process, often driven by budget (value engineering), material limitations, and building codes. The success of the project lies in the fact that the building's essential and dramatic form was successfully realized, even if its surface texture differs from the initial, idealized vision.
refined_keywords: architectural rendering vs reality comparison, skyscraper facade analysis, design intent vs built result, materiality and texture, curtain wall system, panelization and joints, lighting and atmospheric conditions, construction practicality, value engineering, design compromise, architectural visualization

prompt: Please identify each building (<image1>, <image2>, <image3>), summarize their similarities and differences, and explain the meaning conveyed by each architectural design.
clear_prompt: You are given three images of distinct architectural works (<image1>, <image2>, <image3>). Your task is to identify each building, analyze their common theme of 'fusion,' and contrast their conceptual approaches and symbolic meanings. For each building, explain what elements are being fused and for what purpose. Conclude by comparing why the first two are considered successful architectural interventions while the third is often criticized.
keywords: architectural analysis, comparative architecture, deconstructivism, juxtaposition, pastiche, new vs old, East vs West, symbolism in architecture, Bundeswehr Military History Museum, Galleria Gwanggyo, Shijiazhuang hybrid building
ref_text:
These three buildings, while visually distinct, all explore the theme of architectural fusion, but with vastly different approaches and outcomes.

1.  **Bundeswehr Military History Museum (Dresden, Germany):** This is a historic arsenal building dramatically altered by architect Daniel Libeskind. The design fuses the old with the new by piercing the symmetrical, neoclassical structure with a massive, sharp wedge of glass and steel. This is an act of deconstruction. The wedge's viewing platform points toward the area where the firebombing of Dresden began, forcing a confrontation with Germany's complex military history. The aggressive intervention is not merely aesthetic; it's symbolic, breaking the rigid order of the past to create a space for sober reflection on the nature of violence. It is a critically acclaimed fusion where contrast generates profound meaning.

2.  **Galleria Department Store (Gwanggyo, South Korea):** Designed by OMA, this building fuses a private, commercial space with a public pathway. It juxtaposes a monolithic, textured stone facade with a faceted, jewel-like glass loop that carves through the building. This glass loop is a public route, connecting the street to a rooftop garden and containing cultural and retail experiences. The contrast between the opaque 'stone' and the transparent 'jewel' is designed to be visually striking and to attract foot traffic by creating a sense of curiosity and spectacle, which is a primary goal for a commercial building. The fusion is functional and experiential, successfully integrating the building into the urban fabric.

3.  **Hybrid Building (Shijiazhuang, China):** This structure is a literal fusion of Eastern and Western architectural icons: one half is a replica of Beijing's Temple of Heaven, and the other is a replica of the U.S. Capitol. Unlike the other two examples, this is an act of pastiche, simply joining two disparate symbols without any transition or conceptual integration. The intent was likely to celebrate a 'East-meets-West' theme, but the execution is widely criticized as jarring and incoherent. The abrupt seam between the two halves creates a sense of conflict rather than harmony, leading to it being labeled as kitsch or simply 'ugly'.

**Similarities and Differences:**
The core similarity is the combination of distinct styles. However, the critical difference lies in the **method and intent of the fusion**. The Dresden museum and Gwanggyo department store use contrast and juxtaposition to create a new, coherent whole with deep symbolic meaning or a clear functional purpose. They create a dialogue between their parts. The Shijiazhuang building, in contrast, performs a superficial collision of symbols, resulting in a disjointed structure that fails to create a meaningful or aesthetically resolved new identity.
refined_keywords: architectural fusion, comparative analysis, symbolism in architecture, conceptual integrity, historic vs modern architecture, deconstructivism, juxtaposition, pastiche, kitsch, public vs private space, successful vs unsuccessful design, Daniel Libeskind, OMA, Bundeswehr Military History Museum, Galleria Gwanggyo, Shijiazhuang hybrid building

prompt: First, what are <image1> and <image2>? Then, what is the contrast between these two, and what is the meaning of each?
clear_prompt: You are given images of two architecturally distinct towers <image1> and <image2>. Your task is to identify each building and conduct a comparative analysis. First, describe the stark visual contrasts between them in terms of color, texture, and form. Then, for each building, explain the core architectural concept, its symbolic meaning, and how its design relates to its function (residential vs. hospitality).
keywords: architectural contrast, L'Arbre Blanc, W Osaka Hotel, Tadao Ando, organic architecture, minimalism, biomimicry, form vs function, expressive facade, monolithic design
ref_text:
The two buildings presented are L'Arbre Blanc in Montpellier, France, and the W Hotel in Osaka, Japan. They offer a powerful study in architectural opposites, creating immense visual impact through their diametrically opposed designs.

**A Study in Contrast:**
The primary contrast is one of color and form. L'Arbre Blanc is 'pure white' and appears 'bristly' or complex, while the W Osaka is 'pitch black' and 'sleek' or smooth. The French building has an organic, explosive form that reaches outward, creating a textured and dynamic silhouette. The Japanese hotel, by contrast, is a pure, contained monolith, emphasizing its geometric simplicity and smooth surface.

**Meaning and Intent:**

1.  **L'Arbre Blanc (The White Tree):** This 17-story residential tower is a prime example of biomimicry in architecture. Its design is meant to evoke a giant tree or pinecone, with its multitude of balconies and pergolas 'sprouting' outwards like branches and leaves striving to capture sunlight. This expressive form is highly functional, enriching the residents' lives by providing extensive outdoor space and fostering a unique sense of vertical community and neighborly connection. The architecture celebrates openness, nature, and social interaction.

2.  **W Hotel Osaka:** Designed by master architect Tadao Ando, this hotel embodies a powerful and sophisticated minimalism. It is conceived as a 'black magic box'—a stark, mysterious object within the urban landscape. This bold aesthetic perfectly captures the W brand's identity, which aims to break traditions and deliver a 'bold and high-end' experience. The opaque exterior conceals a vibrant and art-filled interior, transforming the building from a mere hotel into an exclusive art gallery. The design plays with themes of mystery, discovery, and curated luxury.
refined_keywords: L'Arbre Blanc Montpellier, W Hotel Osaka, Tadao Ando, comparative architectural analysis, architectural opposites, white organic architecture, black minimalist monolith, biomimicry, tree-like structure, expressive facade with balconies, "black magic box" concept, sleek geometric form, mysterious exterior, residential function, vertical community, luxury hospitality design, W brand identity, curated luxury

prompt: What is this meme (<image1>) trying to say, and what is its meaning?
clear_prompt: You are given a four-panel meme (<image1>) that satirizes the architectural design process. Your task is to provide a comprehensive analysis of its meaning. Explain the narrative progression from the 'Concept Sketch' to the final 'After Construction' result. For each panel, describe the visual changes to the building and explain what real-world stage or influence (e.g., client feedback, budget cuts, engineering constraints) it represents. Conclude by summarizing the meme's core message about the conflict between creative ideals and practical realities.
keywords: architectural design process, concept vs reality, value engineering, client feedback, budget constraints, meme, satire, design compromise, architectural humor
ref_text:
This meme humorously and satirically depicts the progressive degradation of an architectural concept from a beautiful, ambitious idea to a bland, utilitarian box. It illustrates the common conflict between creative vision and real-world constraints.

1.  **Concept Sketch:** This panel shows the architect's initial vision: a modern, aesthetically pleasing building with dynamic curves, a green roof, large glass windows, and a harmonious integration with nature (a central courtyard with a tree). This represents the pure, uncompromised ideal.

2.  **After meeting with Client:** The design undergoes its first simplification. The smooth curves are replaced with cheaper, easier-to-build straight lines and angles. The integrated green roof is reduced, and the courtyard is fragmented. This stage represents the impact of client feedback, which is often driven by budget concerns, personal taste, or a desire for practicality over artistry. The initial dream is compromised to meet the client's demands.

3.  **After Working Drawings:** The design is simplified even further. All aesthetically pleasing elements like the green roof, large windows, and unique form are eliminated. The building is broken down into simple, boxy shapes. This stage represents the influence of 'value engineering,' where engineers, contractors, and budget analysts strip away anything deemed non-essential or too expensive to build. The design is optimized for cost and constructability, sacrificing its soul in the process.

4.  **After Construction:** The final panel shows the built reality: a set of generic, uninspired boxes with small, repetitive windows. It bears almost no resemblance to the original concept sketch. This represents the final, disappointing outcome where the initial vision is completely lost to a series of compromises.

**Overall Meaning:** The meme is a cynical commentary on the creative process, particularly in fields like architecture, design, and software development. It highlights how a great idea can be watered down at every step by different stakeholders (clients, managers, engineers), each with their own priorities (usually cost and simplicity), until the final product is a mediocre shadow of its former potential. It resonates deeply with creative professionals who have experienced this frustrating journey.
refined_keywords: meme, 4-panel comic, satire, architectural design process, concept vs reality, design evolution, progressive degradation, client feedback, budget constraints, value engineering, stakeholder influence, design compromise, loss of vision, creative process

[Text] Does the analysis describe the overall narrative as the 'progressive degradation' of a design concept?

prompt:
Draw a painting based on a Chinese poem. The poem describes a scene with black-tiled, white-walled houses, bamboo, a red sun, and flying birds. Please demonstrate the step-by-step process of creating this painting.

Poem: '何人挥毫扫烟云，黑瓦白墙竹作邻。
一轮赤玉碾虚空，惊雀散作朱砂痕。
但见疏密皆成趣，知是丹青有深意。
莫道此境人间无，半在图中半在心。'
clear_prompt:
Your task is to generate a six-step visual sequence that illustrates the creation of a traditional Chinese ink wash painting based on the provided descriptive poem. The process should unfold in a minimalist style on textured paper, starting from a single element and progressively building a complete scene. The final image should capture the essence of the poem: '何人挥毫扫烟云，黑瓦白墙竹作邻。
一轮赤玉碾虚空，惊雀散作朱砂痕。
但见疏密皆成趣，知是丹青有深意。
莫道此境人间无，半在图中半在心。'
keywords: Chinese ink wash painting, step-by-step drawing, architectural illustration, poem visualization, minimalist art, black tiles white walls, generative art, traditional Chinese painting, bamboo, red sun
ref_text: The creation of this ink wash painting, inspired by a classic poem, is demonstrated through a clear, step-by-step process. The process begins with the simplest core element, a single house with black tiles and white walls, as depicted in <image1>. Following this, the scene expands as more houses are added in <image2>, beginning to form a small, intimate cluster. The composition grows more complex and interesting in <image3>, where the houses are arranged into a dense, overlapping village, perfectly illustrating the poetic idea that 'density and sparseness create interest.' The natural environment begins to take shape in <image4>, where bare bamboo stalks are introduced, framing the village and establishing the 'bamboo as neighbors' theme. The bamboo is then brought to life in <image5> with the addition of expressive leaves, creating a sense of movement and vitality around the quiet homes. Finally, the painting is completed in <image6> with the addition of the two most symbolic elements: a striking red sun ('a wheel of red jade') and a flock of scattered birds ('cinnabar marks'), fulfilling all the key motifs of the poem and bringing the entire artistic vision to a beautiful conclusion.

prompt: Please demonstrate the features of a Siheyuan, from one-entry, two-entry, to three-entry courtyards.
clear_prompt:
Your task is to generate a three-step visual and textual demonstration of the traditional Chinese Siheyuan (courtyard house), illustrating its progressive complexity from a one-entry to a three-entry layout. For each step, generate a corresponding architectural rendering and a description.
1. **One-Entry Courtyard:** Generate an image of a basic Siheyuan with a single courtyard. Explain its fundamental components: the main gate, the central courtyard, the main house (north-facing), and the side houses (east and west).
2. **Two-Entry Courtyard:** Generate an image of a more complex Siheyuan. Explain how it expands upon the one-entry layout by adding a second, inner courtyard, separated from the outer court by an ornamental inner gate. Describe the functional division between the outer court (for guests) and the inner court (for the family).
3. **Three-Entry Courtyard:** Generate an image of a large, multi-layered Siheyuan. Explain that this layout adds a third courtyard and often a rear building (Houzhaofang), creating the most private section of the residence. Discuss how this complex structure reflects the social hierarchy and privacy needs of a large, traditional family.
keywords: Siheyuan, courtyard house, architectural layout, one-entry courtyard, two-entry courtyard, three-entry courtyard, architectural visualization
ref_text: The evolution of the Siheyuan (Chinese courtyard house) is a direct reflection of family size, wealth, and social structure. The progression is demonstrated here in three stages. The most fundamental form is the one-entry courtyard, as shown in <image1>. This layout consists of a single courtyard surrounded by four buildings: the main gate at the south, the main house at the north, and two side-houses to the east and west. It's a self-contained and functional unit for a small family. As a family's status and size grew, they would expand to a two-entry courtyard, depicted in <image2>. This design introduces a separation between public and private spaces. An outer courtyard is used for receiving guests, while an inner, more private courtyard, accessed through a secondary ornamental gate, is reserved for the family. The main house is located in this inner courtyard. The grandest form is the three-entry courtyard, represented by the complex layout in <image3>. This adds yet another layer of privacy and hierarchy, typically with a third courtyard and a rear building at the very back of the compound. This rearmost section was the most secluded, often housing unmarried daughters and female servants. While the third image presents a modern, stylized interpretation, it effectively illustrates the principle of multiple, nested courtyards that define a large-scale, traditional residence, creating a series of distinct spatial experiences within a single architectural complex.
refined_keywords: Siheyuan, Chinese courtyard house, architectural evolution, layout progression, one-entry courtyard, two-entry courtyard, three-entry courtyard, architectural rendering, aerial view, layout diagram, social hierarchy, privacy, functional zones, traditional Chinese architecture

prompt: Show the process of the Eiffel Tower's construction, from the architectural sketch to its gradual completion.
clear_prompt:
Your task is to generate a five-step visual and textual narrative documenting the construction of the Eiffel Tower. Each step should include a relevant image and a descriptive caption explaining that stage of the process.
1. **The Sketch:** Generate the initial architectural drawing of the tower. Explain that this was the conceptual design that won the commission.
2. **Starting the Legs:** Generate a historical-style photograph showing the very beginning of the construction, with the four massive legs starting to rise from their foundations.
3. **First Level Complete:** Generate an image showing the four legs meeting and being joined to form the first level of the tower.
4. **Second Level Complete:** Generate an image showing the tower's construction progressing to the completion of the second level, with the structure's iconic shape becoming clearly visible.
5. **The Finished Tower:** Generate an image of the fully completed Eiffel Tower as it stood in 1889, ready for the World's Fair.
keywords: Eiffel Tower, construction process, historical architecture, step-by-step construction, 19th-century engineering, Paris landmark, World's Fair, architectural drawing, structural engineering
ref_text: The construction of the Eiffel Tower was a monumental feat of 19th-century engineering, documented from its conception to completion. It began with the initial design, as seen in Maurice Koechlin's first structural sketch from June 1884 <image1>. This drawing laid out the fundamental principles of the pylon, including its lattice structure and flared base. Construction on the Champ de Mars began in January 1887. By July 1887, the foundation was complete, and work started on the massive wrought-iron legs of the tower, as captured in the historical photograph <image2>. A critical milestone was reached on March 31, 1888, when the four legs were joined together at the first level, a complex operation that ensured the tower's stability <image3>. The construction then proceeded upwards at a rapid pace. The photograph <image4> shows the tower with its second level completed, clearly revealing its now-iconic silhouette against the Paris skyline. Finally, after just over two years of work, the tower was completed on March 31, 1889. The final image <image5> shows the finished structure, standing at 300 meters, ready to serve as the grand entrance to the 1889 Exposition Universelle (World's Fair).
refined_keywords: Eiffel Tower construction sequence, historical photograph, black and white, 19th-century engineering, architectural drawing, blueprint, structural sketch, Maurice Koechlin, wrought-iron structure, lattice design, Paris, Exposition Universelle 1889

prompt: Identify the buildings in these three images <image1> <image2> <image3>, and describe the common creative concept behind the photo manipulations.
clear_prompt: For the three provided images <image1> <image2> <image3>, please identify the specific landmark or building shown in each. Then, analyze the artistic technique used. What is the common theme or creative approach that connects these three images? Explain how the artist uses hand-held illustrations and forced perspective to interact with the architecture in a playful and imaginative way.
keywords: forced perspective, illustration, architecture, interactive art, playful, creative photography, Stockholm, Istanbul, Gamla Stan, Stortorget, Galata Tower, Norra Tornen, Jenga, optical illusion
ref_text:
These three images are a wonderful series of creative photo manipulations where an artist playfully interacts with famous architectural landmarks using clever illustrations and forced perspective. The common element is the imaginative fusion of a 2D element with a 3D real-world structure, prompted by the unique characteristics of each building.

1.  The first image is set in Stortorget, the historic main square of Gamla Stan (the Old Town) in Stockholm, Sweden. The artist holds up a cartoon-style drawing of a book, perfectly angled so that its 'cover' appears to be one of the colorful, iconic gabled buildings. This creates a whimsical illusion that the building itself is a storybook, with a hand ready to open it.

2.  The second photo features the historic Galata Tower in Istanbul, Turkey. In this piece, a hand holds a drawing of a pencil that is precisely aligned with the tower. The ancient stone structure becomes the body of the pencil, and its conical roof serves as the sharpened tip. It's a clever visual pun that reimagines a famous landmark as an everyday object.

3.  The third image showcases the modern Norra Tornen residential towers in Stockholm. This photo brilliantly plays on the building's distinct, modular, block-like design. A hand is shown appearing to pull out one of the protruding sections, as if playing a giant game of Jenga. This interaction humorously and effectively highlights the unique, stacked-box aesthetic of the architecture.
